name: 中世紀晚期至十八世紀祭壇畫：主題、風格與功能
goals: To increase students’ knowledge of the stylistic and iconographic development of this major species of art work.
To increase students’ knowledge of the historical and cultural background of the art works and to discuss the changes of their function through the ages.
To train students’ ability of analytical description and comparative analysis of form using the correct terminology.
To improve students’ capacity of esthetic judgment.
To instruct students how to read and interpret primary sources and evaluate them with regard to the relevant art works.
To promote students’ competencies to collect and interpret related literature and to encourage them to maintain a critical distance towards scientific opinions.
syllabus:
**Course Arrangement: 16 weeks of in-person sessions + 2 weeks of flexible sessions**

1.  Introduction into the topic—Functions of the altar in Christian liturgy. The emergence of the altarpiece in the Middle Ages: first appearances and early examples. Discussion of content of form of term papers.
2.  Beginnings in Italy: 13th-century altarpieces  (Bonaventura Berlinghieri; Coppo di Marcovaldo). Distribution of the topics for term papers.
3.  Italian Altarpieces around 1300—Cimabue, Duccio, Giotto.
4.  The winged Altarpiece in early Netherlandish painting: Hubert and Jan van Eyck, Rogier van der Weyden, Hugo van der Goes, Hans Memling.
5.  The time of Albrecht Dürer.
6.  Matthias Grünewald, _Isenheim Altarpiece_ (1506–15).
7.  Carved limewood altarpieces: The art of Tilman Riemenschneider.
8.  Masaccio and the beginnings of the Renaissance in Florence.
9.  Early Renaissance in Italy: Piero della Francesca.
10.  Family business and foreigners in Renaissance Venice: Andrea Mantegna, Giovanni Bellini, Donatello.
11.  Italian High Renaissance: The art of Raphael.
12.  High Renaissance in Venice: Giorgione, Titian, Paolo Veronese.
13.  Spain from Late Renaissance to Baroque: El Greco and Velázquez.
14.  Baroque in Rome: Caravaggio and the Carracci.
15.  Northern Baroque: Peter Paul Rubens in Antwerp.
16.  Enlighenment and Romanticism: Caspar David Friedrich. The altar and altarpiece in modern times. Final discussion.
17.  Preparation of the term papers: Introduction to academic writing.
18.  Preparation of the term papers: Group or private counseling.

methodologies.note: Field trip(s) , visits of Christian churches in Taiwan

grading.note: Homework: preparation of topics, weekly reading.
Training of formal analysis. Discussion of texts. ca. 30 min. discussion after each presentation.
30–45 min. presentation with ppt about the topic of the term paper; ca. 30 min. discussion after each presentation.
Term papers of c. 15 pages to be submitted at the end of the semester

prerequisite: ◎Available for junior and senior year B.A. program students (Doctoral program courses excepted) and M.A. program students.
